author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We start with the history of data compression. We define a first-order source, and what it means to compress it. We define entropy. We then state and prove Shannon’s noiseless coding theorem, which gives the optimal compression ratio a first-order source.  

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 16: Data Compression and Shannon’s Noiseless Coding Theorem

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Peter Shor
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We derive the formula for the generating functions of Catalan numbers, and we then use it to give the formula for Catalan numbers.    

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

title: Lecture 7: Generating Functions for Catalan Numbers

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We explain and prove the inclusion-exclusion principle, and apply it to the hat check problem. We go over the coupon collector’s problem. We define what independence of random variables means. 

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 3: Inclusion-Exclusion

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We review Shannon’s noiseless coding theorem. We define prefix free codes and show that they can be efficiently decoded by using a binary tree. We then give Huffman’s algorithm for finding the optimal prefix free code.   

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 17: Huffman Coding

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

Definition of a group; examples of groups: addition mod n, multiplication mod n.Definitions of subgroup, definition of cosets, statement and proof of Lagrange’s theorem. Finally, we apply Lagrange’s theorem to prove Fermat’s little Theorem.  

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 11: Basic Group Theory

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Peter Shor
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We explain how polynomials can be used to construct Reed-Solomon codes, and how to use the fundamental theorem of algebra to compute their minimum distance. We then explain how to decode them.     

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

title: Lecture 20: Reed-Solomon Codes

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We introduce and prove Chernoff’s theorem bounding the tails of sums of random variables. Unlike our previous tail bounds, this assumes that all the variables are independent.  

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

title: Lecture 9: Chernoff Bounds

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Peter Shor
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We show how to take duals for arbitrary linear programs (not just ones in canonical form). We introduce the complementary slackness. Next, we give a physics-inspired proof of strong duality. Finally, we use strong duality to prove Koenig’s theorem.    

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 13: Duality in Linear Programming

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

How do you transmit information reliably over noisy channels? We first discuss simple codes: repetition codes. Shannon’s noisy coding theorem shows much better codes exist. We prove the simplest case of this theorem — for the binary symmetric channel.    

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 18: Transmitting Information Reliably over a Noisy Channel & Shannon’s Noisy Coding Theorem

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
We introduce zero-sum games. We define the payoff matrix. We then give several examples of zero-sum games (matching pennies and a more complicated game). We then explain the concept of Nash equilibrium.


MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We introduce zero-sum games. We define the payoff matrix. We then give several examples of zero-sum games (matching pennies and a more complicated game). We then explain the concept of Nash equilibrium.  

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu

title: Lecture 14: Zero-Sum Games

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Peter Shor
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We explain the problem of maximum flow. First, we show that the maximum flow is always less than the minimum cut. We next write down the linear program for maximum flow and take the dual. It turns out that this gives the minimum cut.     

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 15: Max-Flow Min-Cut Theorem

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We explain what it means for two events to be independent, and what it means to condition one event on another. We cover the law of Total Probability and Bayes’ rule. We then define random variables and expectations, and explain linearity of expectation. 

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 2: Independence and Conditioning

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Peter Shor
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We prove the Cayley tree theorem by counting in two ways. We then explain the basics of generating functions — what is a generating function, and how we combine two generating functions (e.g. adding them and multiplying them).    

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 5: More Counting and Generating Functions

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Peter Shor
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

We show how to use generating functions to solve linear recurrence equations. In particular, we use generating functions to derive an expression for Fibonacci numbers. We then discuss generating functions with two variables.    

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 6: More on Generating Functions

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.200 Principles of Discrete Applied Mathematics, Spring 2024
Instructor: Ankur Moitra
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-200-principles-of-discrete-applied-mathematics-spring-2024
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP61p2fXeXjNCrfNHFwyW-bl0

In this lecture we cover tail bounds; these bound the probability that a random variable is far away from the mean. We give Markov’s bound and Chebyshev’s bound. We then use Chebyshev’s bound to prove the weak law of large numbers.  

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

title: Lecture 8: Tail Bounds
